title-group.article-title: Interfaith Development Efforts as Means to Peace and Witness

abstract.p: Christian development agencies have been the primary vehicle of choice for holistic involvement and witness. This has played straight into an Enlightenment manner of thinking that compartmentalizes values, limiting the opportunities for explaining the theological and conceptual foundations for development practice and for public witness concerning religious faith. New institutional models appropriate to witness and holistic Christian service need to be considered. An `S4' type organization, explored in practice in Indonesia in an interfaith setting, allows for a more effective sharing of the gospel and robust development work.

This has played straight into an Enlightenment manner of thinking that compartmentalizes values, limiting the opportunities for explaining the theological and conceptual foundations for development practice and for public witness concerning religious faith. New institutional models appropriate to witness and holistic Christian service need to be considered. An `S4' type organization, explored in practice in Indonesia in an interfaith setting, allows for a more effective sharing of the gospel and robust development work. development dialogue institutions interfaith peace-making values Keywords Introduction Evangelicals have long shied away from interfaith dialogue. In fact, it might be that one of the historical reasons Evangelicals have been so late in getting involved in development is the suspicion that such involvement might lead them away from the gospel by tying them into secularized modes of reasoning or by diluting the gospel message with alien ideas from other faiths or from skeptical modernist thought.1 Oddly enough, though, it seems probable that biblical witness has in fact been limited precisely by this path Evangelicals have taken.2 An almost exclusive emphasis on the Christian development agency as the primary vehicle of choice for holistic involvement and witness has played straight into an Enlightenment manner of thinking, one that partitions the gospel into divisions and pieces unnat- ural to the message itself. As we shall see, the Enlightenment, by definition, rules out exchange and dialogue about values in the public sphere, a position that sig- nificantly restricts opportunity for public witness concerning religious faith. We shall see that, to the degree anti-Christian bias exists in the world today (and it clearly does, justified or not), Christian development organizations end up faced 68 not only with these biases, but also with a systematic prohibition against explain- ing theological conceptual foundations for development practice in the first place. At the end of the day, Christian development organizations ironically end up co- opted into the Enlightenment's compartmentalization of values. The gospel ends up either domesticated into Christian ghettos or prohibited from being discussed within the ambit of so-called `secular' organizations. Consequently, it is high time new institutional models appropriate to witness and holistic Christian service were explored. This article attempts to initiate just such an exploration. As a result, I put forward a particular type of organization – one I label `S4' – that I believe promises avoidance of these pitfalls by overcom- ing many of the barriers erected by Enlightenment-style values. S4 organizations, by emphasizing the importance of sharing the gospel in an interfaith setting, also allow for more robust development work with greater opportunities for the establishment of biblical conduits of peace in this world so fraught with strife, dissention, terror and war. The Enlightenment Consensus in Disarray: The Cultural Backdrop for Development As Christian development workers we are confronted with a dilemma, one we no longer can afford to ignore: What do we do as the global, secular Enlightenment culture cum consensus crumbles all around us? How do we get on with doing our work, fulfilling our call, in a terrain which makes so little sense if seen through the settled conceptual perspective handed down to us by our forbears? In a word, what should development work undertaken Christianly look like in our present radically-pluralized yet still contentious world? For instance, it is no longer tenable to divide our globe into the discrete, packaged categories of east/west, north/south, developed/developing, secular/religious or Christian/Muslim. The demographic terrain defies such – with Bradford, England boasting thousands of Muslim residents of Pakistani descent, Amsterdam awash in North African and Indonesian citizens, those of Japanese descent consti- tuting a sizeable and influential population group in Sao Paolo, Brazil, and even a quarter of Saudi Arabia's population comprised of foreign workers. And, of course, virtually everyone is aware of the technological interconnect- edness of our world today. One can simultaneously teleconference with several parties situated at the four corners of the globe, receive emailed contracts and return them within a matter of minutes (thereby sealing a deal across continents), view a Hollywood (or Bollywood) movie in the evening in Kiev – one only just released earlier that afternoon a continent away, and transfer funds to a vendor of a Chinese computer program who runs his business out of Beijing – downloading the program and installing it all in the same movement. In sum, not only have we turned into a `global village' à la Marshall McLuhan, but trends and information sweep across the face of the world at such a rate that one notable author has taken to describing our spherical planet as actually `flat' (Friedman, 2005) – meaning that large-scale homogenization has smoothed down and blurred cultural and socio-political not to mention economic differences in a way previously unimaginable. Yet, this coming together has not brought us together. Wars, terror, misun- derstanding and division seem at an all-time high. And since very little cannot be instantaneously broadcast anymore, cartoons published in Copenhagen can prompt riots in Karachi and policies adopted in the USA are just as likely to cause 69 acts of terror in Mumbai, Bali or Yemen as in London, Oklahoma City or New York. It is widely held that this past century – the Enlightenment century par excellence – has been the bloodiest century in recorded history.3 Part of the problem can be found within the very architecture of Enlightenment rationality itself. Lesslie Newbigin explores the arbitrary firewall modern society erects between what might be called the private/value domain and the public/ fact domain.4 It seems that in modernist thinking, `facts' function in the public realm whereas `values' are consigned to operate only within the private. Thus, in the public realm, when one runs into seemingly contradictory features (say, decid- ing whether something is white or black), it is only proper to `argue, experiment, carry out tests, and compare results, until we finally agree on what the facts are; and we expect all reasonable people to accept them ... ' (Newbigin, 1989: 16) (since nothing can be both black and white at the same time). However, a process akin to this does not obtain for the private world of val- ues, a realm where conceptual pluralism of the deepest sort reigns. Provided one keeps private values private, rational contradiction and incommensurable views are allowed to be incompatible in the private sphere, without causing us a bit of cognitive dissonance. This is true since the last remaining universally embraced value left within the public sphere is an adamant prohibition against publicly questioning others' values (Newbigin, 1989: 19).5 Obviously, such an arrangement exhibits a deep self-referential problem, since we end up with a value operating in the public realm as required in order to restrict additional val- ues from going public – for, even the prohibition against airing values in public is itself an airing of values in public. Moreover, keeping those pesky `values' domesticated to the private realm is never as easy as first assumed since heart- felt values tend to (re-)assert themselves at the most inconvenient times and in the most unexpected places (such as on the streets of Paris during riots, or in uncontrolled debates over the Internet). Further complicating matters – according to Jürgen Habermas – is the fact that such an arrangement actually brooks little space for the `public sphere' to thrive in a healthy manner outside of control of the state. Consequently, val- ues no longer are hammered out in public (since a `secular' value system ends up smuggled in and given preference under the guise of its neutrality). This configuration permits late global capitalism the opportunity to exploit com- mercial mass media, thereby shriveling value discourse away and replacing it with instrumentalist bureaucratic and technological rationalism. Such a move leaves people with little public role besides competing for the state's attention, resources and largesse, with nary a chance of shaping the state and its policies. Civil society simply atrophies.6 Aside from the ill effects this has had upon public discourse and value delib- eration, and besides the difficulty it poses for any sincere attempt to publicly bear witness to the Christian faith, a muddled view of truth of this sort ipso facto throws all substantive debate concerning development into question. After all, what is development if it is not an attempt to grapple with and work toward ultimate images of good? Development, itself, is reduced to a technocrat's exer- cise, with the value load inevitably assumed muting all discussion as to what this `good' actually should be. So, the Enlightenment program is in peril – and, with it, all structures and mecha- nisms dependent upon its demarcations, inclusive of the entities we establish as conduits for our own development work. We now can see that secular organizations 70 (including those deemed `development organizations') are not neutral structures; instead, they induce and institutionalize the privatization and belittling of all public faith and deep-value dialogue. While it is true that persons of faith can participate in these, participants must play by the public/private, value/fact rules, giving a final nod to the governing `secular canopy' in place, complete with all of its constraints. While one may discuss certain `liberal' values, such as anti-corruption (honesty, transparency) or democracy (representation of interests, consultation, openness), the discussion must remain sufficiently vague so as to avoid tying the points into values carrying any real mandate for specific change. Such a position obviously runs counter to the very specific message of the gospel, tied as it is into the specific visitation of God in Jesus of Nazareth. Somehow we need organizational structures that permit the broadcast of such a specific narrative, but one that is not so tied to the value-attenuating rules of Enlightenment strictures. The Viability of Christian Development Agencies in Today's Interconnected World Probably in part based upon this outlined dilemma, Christians in development have customarily established distinctively Christian organizations, ones promising open discussion, consideration and propagation of the Christian faith position. The hope seems to be that this will create space for the Christian development worker – space where the above threats and difficulties seem not to be as acutely felt. Also, it is thought, testimony and witness to the faith will thereby be made possible. But, with the appearance of the Christian development agency as institution of choice in answering this dilemma, other challenges loom large – especially in the milieu of today's world as described earlier. It will help us to look at these briefly, one by one. In today's global climate, there is a prevailing anti-Christian bias latent within many alternate faiths and world view systems (inter alia, Islam, nationalist move- ments, and even secularism, as described earlier.) We first must recognize that some of this anti- bias has been of our own making, i.e. the fruit of the way the Christian community over the years has tied itself to colonialism and inequitable power structures. Little wonder that persons from other faith traditions have often viewed us with a jaundiced eye, skeptical of our intentions and our modes of operation. At the same time, though, it also is true that a bit of this bias often amounts to simple prejudiced opposition, the sort of hostility Jesus warned his followers they would face as a matter of course (see Matt. 5:11–12). The gospel is an upside- down message – one that runs counter to typical worldly systems. It should no longer surprise us when we run headlong into it. So, irrespective of the reason, its engendering source or its legitimacy, predis- posed anti-Christian bias is out there. And, since the world currently is such a flat, small, global place, gaining entry into the many regions where the bias obtains is becoming increasingly difficult, to say the least. Nation-states are closing borders and the breakdown of the old colonialist structures (which historically helped to bring about the distrust) means that foreigners find it very difficult to be invited into lands suspicious of their motives. Moreover, even when gaining entry, establishing credibility with local per- sons often proves an extremely difficult thing for a Christian foreign national to do – since the Christian structures which serve as our conduits so readily draw boundaries around us, signing an `us/them' configuration to those we encoun- ter. In other words, our structures connote – from the beginning – that we are 71 exclusively different from these persons, with little points of commonality. This inevitably and consequently alienates them from any invitation to entertain the gospel message right from the start, since following Jesus ends up defined as a membership activity in a foreign organization or institution.7 Second (and complicating matters further), we are confronted with the fact that the boundaries of our Christian structures seem to buttress and confirm certain overarching ideologies and religious perspectives that are predisposed against the Christian message, often not due to history or previous experience, but instead as a part of internal hard-wiring subsumed under local religious world views, so to speak. What I am speaking of here are those ideologies and world view systems whose internal logic runs directly counter to integral portions of the gospel mes- sage itself.8 By way of example we can look at Islam: as a global faith, it is decid- edly anti-incarnational as a part of its self-identity – speaking of a god who became human is theologically dismissed a priori. This being the case, it seems rather self- defeating to begin dialogue based centrally upon points of theology and religious belief – since we often begin with the very points our dialogue partners are so in opposition to. And, this is precisely what we do if we mark our identity through institutional membership, membership that enshrines theological allegiance as its primary defining characteristic. Surely, there must be a better way. I believe there is a better way, one whose contours we shall explore later. Before that exploration, though, it is perhaps helpful to note in passing that cer- tain specialists in the field of development – persons exhibiting no particular affiliation with Christianity or any other world religion – are now calling for increased consideration of and respect for religious perspectives. For instance, Katherine Marshall from the World Bank, in an address given to the Conference on Religious NGOs and Development Institutions in Oslo, Norway in April 2005, calls for the World Bank to be willing and prepared to work with faith-based non-governmental organizations (NGOs) of a variety of types and foci (Marshall, 2005). It seems that Marshall – and others like her –9 are beginning to realize that grassroots development attempts that bypass considerations of religion and faith allegiance not only put the development organization out of step with most resi- dents in tradition-based societies (since to sideline religion in contexts like these is to sideline local world views), it also denies these same organizations access to conceptual resources often religious in nature – such as a religiously-funded will- ingness to deny self, to sacrifice, and to commit to works of integrity and loyalty at great personal expense. With such awareness more and more evident on the part of the World Bank and other global agencies such as this, it behooves us to find structures best suited to step into this ever-widening gap. In Search of Models Offering Opportunity for Collegiality, Empowerment and Witness Realizing and even leveraging off of the conceptual bankruptcy of the Enlightenment program and its accompanying institutions, we now may give our attention to fashioning a renewed mindset with accompanying conduits. These institutions could help us learn to work together with (willing) persons of other faiths and world views, in a manner respectful of both their position and ours. These could be structures that allow partnership, but which also do not compro- mise the need for participants to give witness to their beliefs as they engage in authentic grass-roots development empowerment. The sort of mechanisms I envi- sion will not be secular in nature (since, as we have seen, that modernist form is 72 Figure 1: The S1–S6 Continuum replete with downsides and pitfalls); neither will it be Christian, since the fencing off that these sorts of structures requires demarcates too severely to be of use in the climate we face these days. I have labeled my proposed conduit an `S4' model. Its contours become more obvious as we explore Figure 1,1 0 reviewing, compar- ing and contrasting it with the other varieties on offer. The first thing to notice in this grid is the top row. Listed there are designa- tions borrowed from the late missiologist Paul Hiebert,11 who noted that in set theory, sets can be categorized as either bounded or centered in nature.12 A bounded set is a normal in/out grouping – those outside the boundaries of the set are not members of the set. In Figure 1, boundedness would indicate persons claiming membership within the Christian faith or those outside the Christian faith. In opposition to bounded sets, membership in a centered set is determined not by the set member 's location within boundaries, but rather by the member 's relationship to and direction toward (or away from) the center. Hiebert explains it well: ... A centered set is created by defining the center or reference point and the relationship of things to that center. Things related to the center belong to the set, and those not related to the center do not ... Second, while centered sets are not created by drawing boundaries, they do have sharp boundaries that separate things inside the set from those out- side it – between things related to or moving toward the center and those that are not. Centered sets are well-formed, just like bounded sets. They are formed by defining the center and any relationships to it. The bound- ary then emerges automatically. Things related to the center naturally separate themselves from things that are not ... 73 Third, there are two variables intrinsic to centered sets. The first is mem- bership. All members of a set are full members and share fully in its func- tions. There are not second-class members. The second variable is distance from the center. Some things are far from the center and others near to it, but all are moving toward it ... Fourth, centered sets have two types of change inherent in their structure. The first has to do with entry into or exit from the set. Things headed away from the center can turn and move toward it ... The second type of change has to do with movement toward or away from the center. Distant members can move toward the center, and those near can slide back while still herded toward it ... (Hiebert, 1994: 123–4, emphasis added) Thus, as represented in our graph, centered-set membership indicates not so much where one is positioned in terms of being in or out of Christianity, but instead, it points to one's direction and movement toward relationship with God through Jesus Christ. In other words, using our example of development structures, a bounded set can be illustrated by organizational membership in a Christian development agency – one is either a member or not, a worker or not, a Christian or not. Membership in a centered set development organization, in contrast, would be defined by what the members of the organization were try- ing to accomplish, what they were trying to do, who they were trying to please. These organizations would more be constituted by way of their everyday praxis and ongoing activities – what they were becoming and the long-term goals they embraced. As shown by our following example, this will result in organizations focused upon doing a particular style of grass-roots development work, work that serves as forms of worship to God who wishes for it to be undertaken. This brief explanation of set theory assists us in understanding the categories of the grid described in greater detail below. We now may turn our attention to the different types of structures,1 3 or organizational types represented in Figure 1 – appraising how each type might assist us in development work under- taken in today's radically pluralized context. Advocating an S4 Model S1 represents a classic church group or denomination attempting to do develop- ment work – utilizing structures intimately attached to the church and its image. Thus, the language of the church, primary allegiance to it as institutional home, funding from its coffers, and overt witness closely tied to its purposes are defin- ing characteristics of this model. In the American context, organizations such as Church World Service, Episcopal Relief and Development or the United Methodist General Board of Global Ministries are examples here. S2 and S3 organizations represent the likes of World Vision, Habitat for Humanity or the Tear network in the UK, Australia, New Zealand, the Netherlands, etc. – with the nature of their identity depending a great deal upon toward which constituency they attempt to posture themselves. These organizations are S2 as they focus toward resources and funding obtained from the `church' or the `sending' world, whereas S3 represents, for instance, when World Vision advertises in Time magazine (note that, even there, such an organization demarcates itself as an explicitly Christian organi- zation – thus, its `bounded set' identity). S1–S3, as bounded-set institutions, gener- ally only employ Christians and they reserve positions of leadership for Christians. 74 S5 models launched as such are probably somewhat rare – simply due to the fact that opportunities for initiating these are hard to come by. Such a model is illustrated by a group of Christians covenanting together for the purpose of gain- ing employment at, for instance, a national World Bank office, a USAID, AusAid or GTZ office, or even at a local water sanitation project in-country. These folk are still collective, but they undertake this witness communally in a `secular' context (thus their Christian activities and witness must be privatized – given the nature of the secular context for this type of organization, wherein our earlier analysis of the Enlightenment-, modernist-inspired division of private and public space arises in full force). S6 is where a Christian takes up employment at any of the S5 sort of organiza- tions described above, but this time as a solitary individual, not as a part of a col- lective. Primarily due to this solitary nature, S6 witness – admirable though it is – struggles with effectiveness.1 4 In fact, due to this, it often happens that as various S6 individuals became acquainted with each other within a `secular' organization, they frequently form collectives along the lines of S5 groupings.1 5 Against such a backdrop, S4 begins to look different. First, by taking upon itself a `centered-set' witness focus, it calls to work within its structure anyone who possesses a desire to strive for the betterment of poor populations, irrespective of the religious vision or grand world view the person embraces.1 6 In the case of an institution of this sort operating in an Islamic context, for instance, Muslims and Christians join forces, with the latter afforded the opportunity to witness to the former – but, of course, witness could (and probably would) flow in the reverse direction as well (more on that below). Second, the collective gathering (or koinonia) structure toward that the believers would be working is either housed within the `wineskin' or structure of the NGO or is equal to the NGO (thus, it is still centered-set in nature). This is what is meant by the term `NGO/A-church'. A defining characteristic of an S4 organization is, as a religious organization (but not one promoting a specific religion), all individuals involved within it see `work as worship', though obviously what this worship entails and its qualities is approached from different perspectives, based upon dialogue (and this is where witness and evangelism in dialogue openly takes place).1 7 Thus, from within the framework of an S4 organization, we as Christians are afforded the opportunity to explain our faith without seeming to wander outside that which we are expected to do as development practitioners (this witness can most directly and poignantly be offered to our co-workers, persons holding to a different religious paradigm but who are attempting work similar in goals). In addition, by way of this model we can see why the other models might not prom- ise as much in terms of robust witness, since from within these one is forced to choose between `bounded-set' and `fuzzy-set' stances – postures which either seal us off into ghettoized, fenced-off cloisters (where we are watched and censored so as to keep us from trespassing the boundaries) or which rob us of our distinctive- ness in terms of identity and witness (by way of privatizing our faith and secular- izing our activities). A Brief Look at an S4 Example So, can such a model work? In spite of the theoretical plausibility, is it actually feasible to establish such an organization in a real place with real people? Based upon my own experience involved in an S4 organization in Indonesia over a 10-year period of time, I am happy to report that not only is an S4 institution 75 possible, it has actually been carried out with a good deal of success, in a manner giving credibility to its benefits as described here. Our S4 institution was a NGO that focused upon community empowerment work in various, distinct sectors: primary health care, microfinance, agricultural extension, local community advocacy, handicrafts import and export, and after- school educational programs. The by-laws of our NGO were based upon two pri- mary tenets, ones which undergirded all of our operations: (1) we committed to focus our attention and programs upon the marginalized and neglected, and (2) we intentionally viewed our attempts at empowerment as acts of worship, ones we discursively appraised together as an intentionally pluralistic community. We explicitly recruited workers from the two major religious faiths in Indonesia (those Muslim as well as Christian), inviting all participants to be open and expressive of their faith position, while at the same time challenging them to learn to purposely listen to differing opinions and beliefs embraced by those representing other posi- tions in our community.1 8 As a part of this invitation, we embraced the principle that all truth was God's truth and, as such, its contours would be obvious to us as we discussed our different views in community. In short, we challenged all in our midst to humbly listen to each other, stating our beliefs in clear and undiluted fashion, trusting that God would lead us into truth as we humbly sought it out together. As we became more practiced in this process over time, we got better at it – walls came down and the depths of how we believed were shared. And, for those of us Christians in the NGO, it became easier to rely upon the fact that such a position echoed Jesus' words in the Gospel of John, that as one waits upon the Spirit's guidance, he will lead the believer into all truth.1 9 As tangible examples of how this played out, I will cite two representative events – one related to the Muslim 30-day fast month known as Ramadan, the second linked to an ongoing curriculum designed to cultivate collective delibera- tion in our NGO concerning our differing religious perspectives and the ongoing implementation of our programs. One particular year, each Tuesday over the course of the four weeks of the fast month, we gathered to explore religious perspectives and, afterward, to break the fast together – an event that was designed primarily by the Muslim workers in our organization. For the opening discussion, two questions were posed by the moderator (who was our Human Resources Director): (1) Why do you fast? and (2) How do you see work as worship? The first week, two representative Muslim co-workers shared their perspectives related to these questions; the second week, Christian staff members shared from their perspective, the third week, expatriate staff offered their perspectives, and the fourth and last week, as Coordinator and thus senior staff member for the NGO, I shared my own perspective. Obviously, as we all shared answers to these two questions, considerations of the gospel often took center stage, as we compared and contrasted these with normal prac- tices in grassroots development work and with Muslim perspectives pertaining to these. As Christians, we were able to point to the deeply theological reasons we were engaged in this work – points that were received thoughtfully and with serious consideration. We sensed no discomfort or discord, simply honest interest and a desire to understand each other. This was very different compared to the customary atmosphere in Indonesia at those times when Muslims and Christians found themselves discussing differing religious perspectives. The second, representative case revolved around a discursive training program that we maintained over the course of our work. Every two weeks – on a Friday 76 afternoon after the Muslim weekly prayer event that week – we gathered as an NGO to talk about various topics related to our work; a different person from the organization was slated to lead the discussion each time, after being given oppor- tunity to research the area weeks in advance. Subject matter such as `Gender Issues and Development', or `The True Nature of Participation', or `Specious vs. Authentic Pluralism', or various other comparable themes, constituted the items brought forward for discussion. Inevitably, as each discussion leader guided us through the time together, various views and perspectives were explored – ones amply interlaced and even fraught with religious points of view. Provided the Christians among us could articulate the theological load and nuance of our per- spectives as they related to the issue at hand, it gave us the opportunity to fully share the message of the gospel and its implications. A good many other planned events in addition to these two representative exam- ples became available to us over the course of our work. And, of course, as we worked together in such a centered-set style NGO, innumerable spontaneous and informal occasions for discussion presented themselves to us as we engaged in our S4 work with our Muslim colleagues. These were opportunities of deep sharing which would simply have not been possible within a Christian organization or a secular one. Summarizing the Benefits of S4 Now that prospects for deep level development work, for peace-making and for witness to the Christian faith are more readily before us, it seems that the time might be ripe for us to make concerted efforts toward fashioning bona fide S4 development organizations. As one looks more closely at the model as we have above, its benefits become clear, especially as we remember the globally linked, highly secularized, `flat' world climate we now inhabit: 1 S4 structures allow for legitimate, integrated identity as development workers as we go about our lives in community. With this, a holistic and integrated approach to witness and community empowerment can be maintained, one which need not betray nor disappoint anyone by claiming to be secular while still carrying out religious activities that, in that framework, irt dangerously with proselytization. 2 S4 structures make space for witness and religious identity before co-workers of different religions as well as before secular on-lookers – without a `cloak and dagger' approach of posing as one thing (a development worker) but appearing to be another (a missionary or evangelist). Kingdom-oriented (Christian) development workers are precisely who they say they are – since they have so woven their faith perspective into their work that simply going about it, day-to-day, in the presence of co-workers of other faiths gives testimony to the content of their beliefs. Holistic evangelization and witness happens as a matter of course, as they work. Such a posture is full of integrity and thereby reduces the likelihood the Christian worker will be seen as merely acting to `Christianize'. 3 S4 structures serve as a sort of institutional umbrella – what sociologist Peter Berger calls a `plausibility structure' – enabling the birth of small group-style fellowships under their umbrellas. These small groups can be birthed without extraction of persons from their communities and they are engendered in the midst of robust social involvement that campaigns toward justice. 4 S4 structures allow for a larger pool of potential workers for the development organization – since we need not hire from an exclusively Christian pool of candidates. No longer are we left trying to choose between faithful Christians with little development knowledge, skills and potential, and Christians with development knowledge but who possess little maturity of character. And since we may speak openly about our theological funding and its ethical and personal requirements 77 (in dialogue with all members of the organization), we may be clear what sort of character qualities we require on the part of potential co-workers. If it turns out that non-Christians consistently exhibit those qualities, we hire them, holding them to the standards of our biblically-inspired model. 5 S4 structures are true to the gospel mandate (centered as they are on development work and, thus, works of kingdom manifestation and poverty alleviation). This is the case since S4 groupings are conceptually funded by holistic witness – they authentically aim at empowerment of the poor and concerns related to peace and justice. 6 Related to this point, the internal climate of S4 structures must be based on mutual respect, dialogue and humble listening. Hubristic bravado and a will to win should be given no space within S4 organizations. We must remember that, for the Christian, conversion is a gift of God, prompted by a movement of the Spirit. As E. Stanley Jones reportedly once said, there is a great difference between being God's witness and being God's lawyer; we are called to tell God's story, not to argue God's case. 19 Thus, the follower of Jesus simply learns how to announce God's story as found in Jesus and the way it intersects with his or her story, leaving the results to God's Spirit. S4 structures take this caution very seriously, letting God give evidence of his work in our midst as we, his followers, remain faithful to him in work and worship, taking opportunity to recite his story in community. There is much in common here with J. H. Bavinck's concept of elenctics, a term he uses to refer to the Holy Spirit's action of convicting persons of sin (cf. John 16:8).20 Thus, the Christian has no privileged position in this process – something that opens up space for dialogue and mutual respect. With this, S4 organizations can be havens of peace, dialogue and harmony, while at the same time serving as venues of lively discussion and mutual understanding. Clearly, S4 organizations offer an alternative to the secular as well as to the Christian development organization models. At first, S4 organizations will not be readily understood by the majority in our secularized, Enlightenment-steeped settings – including those from the Church. But, that should not discourage us, since the benefits they promise – especially when seen in light of the problems of our present secularized age – certainly outweigh the consequent confusion they prompt and the explanation they without doubt require. A final comment needs to be made about the style of development work best suited to these S4 organizations. Grassroots, empowerment styles of intervention unquestionably best fit the S4 model described here. This is primarily due to the fact that the `deep grammar' or `methodological style' of many grass-roots, par- ticipatory methods seem to mirror the movement that is at the heart of the gospel message, a movement which shows that when God wished to help the human race in all of its poverty, he incarnated in our midst – as Eugene Peterson says in The Message, Jesus `moved into the neighborhood' (John 1:14). What we are in search of are interventions that mimic the life and trajectory of Jesus, ones that allow us to have the same mind `that was in Christ Jesus' (Phil. 2:5) who, `though he was in the form of God, did not regard equality with God as something to be exploited, but emptied himself, taking the form of a slave ... ' (Phil. 2:6–7). The sort of development styles that can (and should) be proffered and pro- moted in S4 organizations are types which require development practitioners to go about their work humbly, with simplicity, building rapport over time in local neighborhoods of privation. Methods similar to Robert Chambers' `Participatory Rural Appraisal' probably best fit the S4 model –2 1 since, by promoting this sort of style, Christians and non-Christians alike can work side-by-side attempting to implement it – and then, talk about it in community afterwards.2 2 78 It is my contention that if the gospel is true (and I believe it is!), and if the Holy Spirit truly embodies and empowers his people to do works of the kingdom (and I believe he does!), then these two facts can combine to cause Christians to shine before their already sympathetic non-Christian co-workers, prompting questions related to how such quality and level of work consistently flow from us over time. These, of course, are questions we surely would like to entertain – these are elenc- tic moments, born of dialogue and humility. Best of all, both questions asked as well as answers provided can find their genesis in the style and type of develop- ment work we as Christians are doing. S4 structures allow for that type of conflu- ence of message and task, since they require the work to be undertaken side-by- side with those who share our aspirations, but who do not yet know our secret. We would like to let them in on the secret, wouldn't we? With S4 structures, we not only announce the secret, we get the privilege of dramatizing it before a very sympathetic audience, day-in and day-out.
